Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this proposal is to request support for the PI to organize the 2015 NSF CPS PI Meeting. This meeting convenes all Principal Investigators of the National Science Foundation Cyber-Physical Systems Program for the fifth time since the program began. The PI Meeting is to take place on November 16-17, 2015 in Crystal City, Arlington, Virginia. The PI meeting is an annual opportunity for NSF-sponsored CPS researchers, industry representatives, and Federal agencies' representatives to gather and review new CPS developments, identify new and emerging applications, and to discuss technology gaps and barriers. The program agenda is community-drive and includes presentations (oral and poster) from PI's, reports of past year program activities, and showcase/pitch new CPS innovations and results.

The annual PI Meeting serves as the only opportunity where the CPS researcher community gathers to share their research, discuss new research opportunities and challenges, and explore new ideas and partnerships for future work. Furthermore, the PI meeting is also an opportunity for the academic research community to interact with industry entities and government agencies with vested interest in CPS research and development. The PI Meeting is a forum for sharing ideas across the CPS community. It has played a major role in growing the community across broad range of sectors and technologies, and performing outreach to others who have interest in learning about the program and participating as future proposers, transition partners, or future sponsors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigators’ (PI) Meeting marked the sixth annual gathering of over 350 CPS researchers, Government program directors, industry representatives, and other stakeholders who came together to discuss new and ongoing programs in CPS research being pursued by U.S. government research sponsor agencies. This two-day forum allowed nearly 300 PIs to inform and showcase their research results and accomplishments; to discuss challenges (gaps and barriers) and research approaches; to identify new, emerging problems, developments, and opportunities; and to interact and network to forge new collaborations with colleagues in academia, industry, and Federal agencies program managers, and other research organizations.

Major discussions at the program included emphasis on the future of the CPS program, keynote addresses by a White House official about its vision for Smart and Connected Communities as well as an address from Microsoft Research about its Premonition project, a collaboration with other academic researchers and IARPA, which integrates Unmanned Air Vehicles with a CPS software stack to trace the flow of infectious diseases, and the transformation of the CPS Virtual Organization from an information repository into an active destination for facilitating collaboration and research across the community and serving as an essential hub in addressing the grand challenges of the future.

Following is a breakout of the participation metrics and artifacts collected:

1.      Actual Attendance Metrics:

  • Total number of actual attendees – 352
  • Total number of CPS Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs attendees – 271
  • Total number of Government attendees – 40
  • Total number of industry attendees – 7
  • Total number of student attendees – 38
  • Total number of non-PI academics and Others – 7
  • Others – 2

 2.      Registration Metrics:

  • 401 total number of online registrants (based on pre-meeting data collected), including:
  • Total number of CPS Lead PIs, PIs, and Co-PIs attendees – 271
  • Non-PI academics - 7
  • Government representatives – 45
  • Industry representatives – 7
  • Students – 38
  • Others (NSF-Retired, AIT, Project Staff) – 16

 3.      Artifacts Metrics: The following artifacts were generated from the listing of 348 unique research grant awards for this meeting: 

  • 35 keynotes, invited talks, and R&D project presentations were introduced representing a broad range of disciplines have been archived.
  • 158 project abstracts were submitted by PIs
  • 158 project posters were presented at the programmed poster session and have been archived.
  • 44 project videos have been submitted
  • 22 unique demonstrations by respective PIs were presented "live" in real-time.

All public artifacts, including website Urls, speaker presentations, position papers, the meeting program, meeting participant lists, and meeting organizers have been disseminated to communities of interest via the public website for the 2015 CPS PI Meeting that can be found at http://cps-vo.org/group/PIMtg2015. All program committee working documents are stored on the program committee’s private working group website at http://cps-vo.org/group/pimtg15-pc. These websites are permanently archived on the CPS VO, a web portal, which is managed and operated by Vanderbilt University’s Institute for Software Integrated Systems with funding support from NSF.
